data.title: What is MATLAB? All You Need to Know
data.meta_description: MATLAB stands for Matrix Laboratory. It is a programming language that acts as an interactive environment for numerical computation, visualisation & programming.
data.text:
Users comprising of engineers and scientists worldwide use MATLAB to create data models and simulations. But what is MATLAB? Well, this software tool is designed to process massive amounts of data and present it to users in visually interactive formats.

According to the 2021 Gartner Magic Quadrant, MathWorks is a leading name for Data Science and Machine Learning disciplines. The platform is well known for its execution capabilities. MATLAB stands for ‘Matrix Laboratory’. It is a programming language that acts as an interactive environment for numerical computation, visualisation & programming. The following piece of literature will shed some light on What is MATLAB, read along to learn more.

1) An introduction to MATLAB

2) A brief look at the MATLAB environment

a) Add-Ons in MATLAB

An introduction to MATLAB

MATLAB, short for ‘Matrix Laboratory’, is a software environment used by countless engineers and scientists globally for the analysis and design of systems and products. The software is designed using the Matrix programming language, which is a modelling language in a textual format. The language is specifically used to help express computational mathematics in the most natural ways through computing systems.

MATLAB uses built-in graphics to make it significantly easy for users to create visualizations and gain data-driven insights. The workspace environment of MATLAB projects especially encourages users to experiment, explore, and discover processes and ideas during their use. The software tools and operational capabilities present in features of MATLAB have been extensively tested and developed to work together.

Furthermore, the desktop environment of MATLAB is tuned for iterative analysis and design processes. The interface of MATLAB array is easy to use and offers a wide range of functions and toolboxes. The environment has a built-in Live Editor for users to create their scripts to combine code, output, and any formatted text in one executable notebook.

More importantly, MATLAB Commands allows its users to observe the working mechanism of various algorithms with their data. Users can also perform iterations until they are satisfied with the results they desire. The program can also help users automate their work. The capabilities of the software range from Data Analysis, App Development, and Hardware to Web Deployment, Parallel Computing, and Cloud Operation.

A brief look at the MATLAB environment

The MATLAB environment helps users run a multitude of commands, manage their files, and view program results. Users can adjust the desktop layout and customise their usage preferences, such as fonts, keyboard shortcuts, and set their working folder path:

Add-ons in MATLAB

The MATLAB software empowers users to extend the capabilities of the environment by providing additional functionalities through 'add-ons.' These supplementary components are designed for specific applications and activities, including but not limited to additional algorithms, interactive applications, and seamless connections to various hardware devices. The integration of these add-ons enhances the versatility and adaptability of MATLAB operators, enabling users to tailor the software to their specific needs and broaden its utility in diverse fields and projects.

The built-in add-ons can be accessed from MathWorks, the website that created MATLAB and Simulink. MathWorks creates products for data analysis and simulation. Additional products can also be accessed from the global MATLAB user community. These products include extra applications, toolboxes, and support packages. Some key examples of add-on categories are Physical Modelling, Real-Time Simulation and Testing, Event-based Modelling, Parallel Computing, Systems Engineering, Digital Signal Processing, and more.

Capabilities of MATLAB

The MATLAB environment has a myriad of capabilities that help users in their development processes. The software is utilised by engineers and scientists for organising, cleaning, and analysing complex sets of data from a range of fields like Climatology, Medical research, Finance, and Predictive Maintenance.

Here are some key capabilities included by MATLAB:

Data Analysis

1) Capabilities for pre-processing and handling engineering and scientific data types.

2) Creation of interactive and customisable data visualisations.

3) Additional applications and a Live Editor with tasks to help users clean and prepare their data, as well as generate code.

4) Many pre-built functionalities for data analysis, signal processing, and machine learning.

5) Professionally and extensively written documentation.

6) Simple program changes with accelerated performance and additional hardware support.

7) Ability to expand analysis to big data without significant changes to the code.

8) Data can be analysed and automatically packaged into software components that are freely distributable or embedded source code without the need for manual recoding of algorithms.

9) Automatic report generation based on analysis results, which can be shared with others.

Graphics

1) MATLAB provides built-in plots that allow users to visualise their data, identify patterns and trends, and gain data-driven insights.

2) Integrated documentation allows users to explore function syntax and various chart options.

3) Users can select from various relevant data plots based on the data they have selected and find the most optimal visualisation for their needs.

4) Visualisations can be explored and annotated by users without requiring extensive coding.

5) MATLAB's graphics system can be extended with customised defaults to suit the user's preferences, which can be shared with colleagues to implement a common standard across the team.

Parallel Computing

1) MATLAB allows users to perform data computations on a large scale and create parallel simulations by utilising multi-core systems, GPUs, clouds, and clusters.

2) Users can solve computationally intensive data problems by leveraging available computing resources.

3) Users can also directly take advantage of NVIDIA GPUs from the MATLAB software.

4) MATLAB allows users to run various Simulink simulations in parallel.

5) Users can design prototypes on their desktops and scale them to the clouds and clusters using MATLAB.

6) Users can benefit from the Parallel Computing Toolbox, which gives them control over their local multi-core processors and GPUs, helping to speed up their work.

7) The toolbox also includes high-level constructs that help users parallelise their MATLAB applications without needing MPI (Message Passing Interface) or CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture).

8) Parallelising is a MATLAB functionality that enables running various processes performing the same calculations with different data and using different processors.

9) Users can prototype their applications on the desktop application and then scale to the clouds by using the MATLAB Parallel Server without the need to recode.

Cloud Computing

1) Users can leverage the power of MATLAB and Simulink to accelerate their development processes by accessing on-demand resources for enhanced computing and reliable data storage.

2) By using the online versions of MATLAB and Simulink, users can access both tools through their web browsers. Additionally, users can connect to their cloud data and take advantage of various cloud services, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure.

3) MATLAB and Simulink make it easy for users to scale their long-running computation programs to CPUs, GPUs, and even computer clusters in the cloud, enabling faster and more efficient processing of their data.

Desktop and Web Deployment

1) MATLAB provides users with the ability to share their work as standalone applications or Docker containers with collaborators or clients who may not have licensed software versions. These unlicensed users can access shared deployments without any royalties involved. MATLAB Runtime is a standalone version that includes a pre-built collection of shareable libraries that allow compiled MATLAB programs to be executed.

2) To protect their programs, users can use industry-standard encryption protocols. The MATLAB Runtime application can reduce the size of deployed applications before sharing.

3) Cross-platform support is also available, allowing users to develop their MATLAB applications and APIs on one system and deploy them to other platforms.

4) Organisations can integrate their algorithms and data analytics with their enterprise systems throughout the DevOps lifecycle.

Cross-environment Execution

1) Users can benefit from MATLAB’s Engine APIs by executing MATLAB code within external programming environments. These APIs allow MATLAB code to be executed from within the programming language of the user’s choice, eliminating the need to start a new desktop session of MATLAB.

2) MATLAB’s Engine APIs support many programming languages, such as C, C++, Java, Python, and Fortran. Users can call functions and objects written in other programming languages from within the MATLAB environment. Components across a wide range of libraries, such as C++, Java, Python, .NET, and Fortran, can be called.

3) Users can also extend the functionality of their algorithms by converting their MATLAB algorithms into C or C++ code using MATLAB Coder.

Applications of MATLAB

Users can utilise the MATLAB environment for many applications spanning various domains. Here are some key domains discussed:

1) Data analytics

Employing MATLAB in data analytics empowers professionals to delve into data intricacies efficiently. This proves particularly advantageous in financial assessments where MATLAB facilitates the evaluation of critical factors such as profitability, solvency, liquidity, and organisational stability. The robust environment MATLAB provides ensures a comprehensive approach to economic assessments.

2) Control systems

MATLAB is a pivotal platform for crafting sophisticated control systems for various industrial applications. Users harness MATLAB's capabilities to create control loops, issue commands to multiple system components, and finely regulate their behaviour. Including the control system toolbox facilitates the analysis of algorithms and the design of linear control systems, making MATLAB an indispensable resource for control engineering.

3) Embedded systems

The support MATLAB extends to embedded systems is marked by a unique feature—a "push button" functionality that generates and executes code on hardware effortlessly. This capability is instrumental in developing various embedded applications, ranging from household devices like microwaves to advanced technologies like cameras and printers.

4) Motor and power control

MATLAB algorithms play a crucial role in the development of motor control strategies. By focusing on precision control, energy efficiency, and system protection, MATLAB reduces the time required for algorithm development. This cost-effective strategy allows engineers to refine algorithms before committing to extensive and expensive hardware testing.

5) Test and measurements

The conventional practice of testing and measuring electronic products is enhanced significantly by MATLAB. Engineers benefit from a suite of tools that automate tasks and facilitate live visualisation and data analysis. This aids in ensuring product quality by identifying material defects through physical examinations and verifying functionality through rigorous testing.

6) Digital signal processing

In digital signal processing, MATLAB simplifies complex signal-processing operations. It becomes a unified environment for users, allowing them to employ signal processing techniques when dealing with time series data. The streamlined workflow provided by MATLAB proves invaluable for developing streaming applications and embedded systems.

7) Robotics and mechatronics

Robotics, a multidisciplinary field, finds MATLAB an all-encompassing environment for researchers and engineers. MATLAB supports the design, simulation, and implementation of algorithms for various types of robots. Similarly, in mechatronics, where multiple scientific fields converge, MATLAB facilitates the design and simulation of integrated subsystems, encompassing electrical, mechanical, control, and embedded software.

8) Image processing and computer vision

The image processing capabilities of MATLAB are harnessed for enhancing images through pixel manipulation, utilising advanced mathematical techniques. Moreover, MATLAB proves instrumental in computer vision applications, enabling the building of algorithms for facial beauty enhancement and barcode scanning.

9) Predictive maintenance

Predictive maintenance, a critical engineering aspect, is enhanced through MATLAB's predictive maintenance toolbox. Engineers leverage MATLAB to level data, design condition indicators, and estimate the remaining useful life of machinery. This aids in strategic maintenance planning, ensuring optimal equipment performance.

10) Wireless communication

MATLAB's contribution extends to wireless communication, where engineers collaborate efficiently. MATLAB is a collaborative platform that reduces development time by facilitating idea exchange and early identification of design issues. Additionally, MATLAB offers streamlined testing and verification processes for wireless devices, ensuring their reliability and performance.

Advantages of MATLAB

The MATLAB environment provides several advantages to users and developers across major industries. The simulation software offers beneficial development tools to improve the performance of code. Here are the key advantages of MATLAB:

1) MATLAB offers a vast database of built-in algorithms that users can utilise for image processing and developing computer vision applications.

2) Users can test their algorithms immediately without the need to recompile the program. The ability to observe results quickly enhances the development of algorithms.

3) Users can work interactively with their data, keep track of program files and simplify the debugging process.

4) MATLAB lets users call external objects and libraries such as OpenCV, an open-source computer vision and machine learning software.

5) Documentation is clearly written and substantiated with various examples.

6) The software’s capability to process still images and videos.

7) Users can receive prompt technical support from a well-trained organisation.

8) A massive developer community exists, providing a large volume of shared knowledge and free-to-use code.

Disadvantages of MATLAB

While MATLAB offers significant advantages for development and simulation of data models, there are also some disadvantages to using the software: MATLAB is an interpreted language, which means that it is generally slower to execute code compared to compiled languages like C and C++.

a) MATLAB can be expensive compared to other programming languages like C or Fortran compilers.

b) To achieve optimal performance, MATLAB requires a computer with sufficient memory, which can add to the cost of programming.

c) The software is dependent on the operating system, which can make it difficult to develop real-time applications.

To fully utilise MATLAB, users must purchase a licensed version of the software from MathWorks.

Conclusion

We hope you’ve read and understood our blog on What is MATLAB. The applications of MATLAB span across domains ranging from General implementations to Aerospace and Digital Signal Processing. The MATLAB language is relatively easier to grasp than many other languages and is a high-level language making it convenient for beginners to start making prototypes. Its cross-platform capabilities let developers deploy and share applications with others and to the cloud.
